reviewText: John Bacchus's Playmate of the Apes is priceless.  Full of silly humor, camp, and beautiful actresses galore, this film is sure to please fans of many genres.It's the distant future.  After awaking from a long hyper-sleep aboard their space shuttle, three beautiful astronauts, Commander Gaylor (Seduction Cinema's poster girl Misty Mundae), Lt. Fornication (newcomer Sharon Engert), and Lt. Pushkintucushkin (adult internet star Anoushka) accidentally push a wrong button and crash land on a mysterious planet.  After trudging through the hot desert/forest, the trio discover that the planet is ruled by human-hating apes.  The apes are convinced that humans have no soul, as the few humans that also populate their planet cannot talk or dance.  Soon we meet many colorful characters: General Lade (John Bacchus), the leader of the apes who fuels the hatred of the humans, Dr. Cornholeus (Debbie Rochon), an ape doctor who is convinced that humans are not as bad as everyone thinks, and Uvula (Seduction star Darian Caine), one of the planet's curious and naive native humans who takes a liking to the astronauts.  Many problems erupt, as the human astronauts cause confusion among the ape population, since they can talk, etc., which negates the notion that all humans are soulless creatures.  Soon, it becomes a battle of wits, strength, and erotic charm as the astronauts try to help the native humans regain their dignity while also trying to repair their ship and return home.Playmate of the Apes is Seduction Cinema's biggest and most prolific stab at the erotic spoof genre so far.  There is a large cast, great monkey make-up, many computer generated effects, and a good, cohesive story.  The three leads (Mundae, Engert, and Anoushka) do a good job at playing their fish-out-of-water roles, and know how to deliver the humorous lines.  Just watch the scene in which Misty Mundae apes the famous line from the original and frantically shrieks, "This place is a madhouse! A MADHOUSE!!" and try not to laugh.  The parody really works.There are many more good things I could say about this film, but it would just be best to see it for yourself.  It's funny, erotic, and very entertaining.The Special Edition DVD presents the film in it's original full-frame aspect ratio.  Special Features are abundant.  They include:*Interviews with Misty Mundae, Debbie Rochon, and Darian Caine*A wonderful behind-the-scenes segment*Sexy, intimate interviews with Anoushka and Sharon Engert*music video for "We're the Humans" (a parody of the Monkee's theme song)*numerous trailers for this and other Seduction Cinema filmsGreat movie, great DVD...director John Bacchus continues to impress.**HIGHLY RECOMMENDED**
summary: another great parody from Seduction Cinema
Title: N/A

reviewText: Seduction Cinema releases a lot of low-budget independent films, but the best ones are those directed by John Bacchus. This is one of them, and it stands as the finest "erotic parody" he has made so far. Not only does the script make fun of both the original "Planet Of The Apes" and the recent re-make, but the film itself is the largest and most expensive production Seduction Cinema has given us to date. The jokes are also getting funnier as well, I'm happy to say. I laughed out loud several times at this movie, and not because it was cheeseball. This movie is genuinely well-written and well-acted. Misty Mundae does a great job at handling the lead role, Darian Caine is incredible as usual (despite having no dialogue...this would be a 5-star affair if Caine & Mundae switched roles), and even John Bacchus is funny as hell playing General Laid (in full ape makeup). My favorite role, however, is that of Doctor Cornholius, played by Debbie Rochon. She totally gets into the part, yet manages to put enough of her own personality and acting style... A great step forward from an already brilliant director, and yet another gem in my collection of Seduction Cinema DVDs.
summary: Yet Another Reason To "Go Ape" Over Seduction Cinema!

reviewText: Words all but fail me when it comes to attempting to convey how bad this thing actually is. Although it may claim to be "satire," one requirement of satire is that... there actually be some humor present. That would be difficult to achieve, since as far as I can tell the script was written by a misogynistic nine-year-old boy weaned on a steady diet of "The Benny Hill Show." Satire takes some actual brain-wattage; none is present here.The actresses portrayed on the box art are *nowhere near so alluring* in the actual film, although to be fair there are women present who look even worse than they do.So, in short, if you enjoy seeing physically unpleasing women continually make out with each other, [and generating all the heat of the average mini Christmas tree light bulb in doing so... and I mean just ONE BULB, not an entire string of lights] you may like this. A love of silicone implants and bad poetry will also stand you in good stead. Everyone else with a working brain, steer clear. It is one of those things of which may honestly be said, "I am now stupider for even having SEEN that."The only reason it gets one star is because 0 stars is not an option.
summary: One of the worst films I have ever, ever seen.

reviewText: Wow!!!This is such an entertaining film. It has georgous women, a decent plot line "humans have no soul cos they can't dance" and side-splitting laughs. Theres rapping, space travel, action and lots of tender moments shared between the female characters. This film is a better remake of the classic flick planet of the apes than that dead boring snore fest starring 'Markie Mark', Misty and Debbie can rap better than he ever did!This was the first seduction cinema flick that I have ever seen and I must say that I am inpressed. I watch films soley to be entertained and this obsolute riot of a movie is so wonderfully over the top that it is impossible not to love it. The jokes all worked for my and the girl on girl scenes are steamy and there is such energy visible on the picture, more so than most "a grade" films.The DVD has plenty of extra's and trailers for a slew of other seduction cinema releases.

reviewText: First off, I am writing this as someone who enjoys spoofs of movies and who rarely watches adult films.Compared to Gladiator Eroticus, I was amazed at the amount of substance to this movie. There is a truly developed story here. The humor has become more intelligent - with some political references. The acting is inconsistant but improving. Also, who would have thought you'd see CGI in this type of movie? The images of the ship in space are pretty good. Naturally, it's not ILM, but still nice. Some of the leading apes are in makeup (with Bacchus having the best of them) and some in masks. For those in make-up, Bacchus' mouth moves more realisticly than the others. For some of the others, the lower mouth piece was applied in a way that prevented it from moving as much when they talked.The plot combines elements from both versions of the movie. The ending represents a nice twist on the Tim Burton's movie ending - which is similar to the book's ending. I can't really discuss it without spoiling it. It's not as stupid as some people may think. ...just twisting a theory around a bit. ...or alot.I'm not sure if this was done for budget reasons or if it was planned, but this could be more loyal to the original book than any of the mainstream movies. In the book, apes live in a modern world - wearing the same clothes we do, living in the same type of houses. There are apes wearing clothes in this production. There is also a club setting that could be an actual local bar or someone's bar at his home. You also have apes using phones here. However, I doubt they were using the book for this version because the humans would have even less clothes. In the book, humans are truly animals acting on instinct and wearing no clothes. In fact, the book's humans rip off the clothes of the astronauts. That's something that could have been played on here.All of the sex scenes are girls only. ...which is typical for this studio.The DVD has some nice extras. There are two trailers for the movie. The interviews and behind-the-scenes segments are nice and look more like what you'd see for mainstream movies. In the interviews, the actors talk with a poster of the movie in the background. There is also a music video of "We're The Humans" - based on The Monkees theme song.This DVD is the most enjoyable one from this group I've seen so far.
summary: The Best Yet From This Group
